results.title: Paddington and the 'old master'
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The wonderful world of Paddington Bear”.
Paddington and the Old Master is adapted from Chapters 4, 5 and 8 of “A Bear called Paddington” by Michael Bond. Paddington learns from Mr Gruber, an antique dealer, that old masterpieces are sometimes covered by newer paintings and that the “old master” can be restored. Paddington decides to apply this technique to one of Mr Brown’s paintings with disastrous results. Suitable for lower and middle primary levels.

results.title: Too much off the top
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The wonderful world of Paddington Bear”
During the slow season at Mr Gruber’s antique shop, Paddington decides to help his friend by repairing a cracked vase. While carrying the vase home he notices a “Help Wanted” sign in a barber shop window. He takes the job, thinking it will be a perfect way to make some extra money for Mr Gruber. Based on the book ‘Paddington at work’ by Michael Bond.

results.title: Mr Curry takes a bath
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The wonderful world of Paddington Bear”.
During winter, the Browns have a bath house and sauna built in their backyard. Mr Curry notices the new sauna and decides to try it for himself. This dismays Paddington and the Browns, since not even Mr Brown has had a chance to use it. Paddington offers to put his combination padlock on the door to keep Mr Curry out but mistakenly locks himself in. Paddington fumbles with the lock but Judy eventually manages to open it. Narrated by Michael Hordern.

results.title: The Car man: Pininfarina
results.creator_credit: Denis Postle, Anthony de Lotbinière and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Pacemakers”.
Pininfarina, the world’s greatest name in automobile design, founder of a firm which builds 25,000 car bodies a year, and designs many others. Farina has used his uncanny feeling for the look and shape of cars to build a unique industry - an industry which is ideally suited to a comparatively small industrial nation like Italy, and which has given her a reputation unequalled in the world. Commentary written and spoken by Anthony Jay.

results.title: Master builder: Pier Luigi Nervi
results.creator_credit: Denis Postle, Anthony de Lotbinière and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Pacemakers”.
Nervi is first and foremost a master craftsman, but he also has an original and revolutionary creative mind. He has an obsession for what he believes to be the supreme building material - a type of reinforced concrete. With it he has built some of the world’s most famous buildings, faster and cheaper than anyone else. The buildings for the Rome Olympics, the Pirelli building in Milan, the Unesco building in Paris, have helped build Nervi’s international reputation as a builder of tomorrow. Commentary written by Anthony Jay, spoken by Brian Redhead.

results.title: The Man who knows: Marcus Wallenberg
results.creator_credit: Denis Postle, Anthony de Lotbinière and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Pacemakers”.
Marcus Wallenberg is not the only man behind Sweden’s success, but he is almost certainly the most outstanding. A study of his methods gives an insight into Sweden’s prosperity. He and his brother Jacob are each chairman of ten companies and on the boards of a further fifty, and are closely involved with five of Sweden’s eight leading firms. Through the drive of men like the Wallenbergs Sweden, with a population of only seven and a half million, has become an object lesson for the smaller industrial nations of the world.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Denis Postle, Anthony de Lotbinière and BBC-TV

results.title: A Man of the world: H.H. the Aga Khan
results.creator_credit: Georges Robin, Anthony de Lotbinière and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Pacemakers”.
The Aga Khan is the creator of one of the world’s most dramatic and imaginative development schemes - a planned riviera along 35 miles of Sardinia’s Costa Smeralda. He is also the spiritual leader of more than 12 million Ismaili-Muslims scattered around the world, and a wealthy Parisian, racehourse owner, and Olympic skier. Shows the Aga Khan in a variety of activities. He comments personally, analysing himself and his different faces with the same detached lucidity he brings to all his undertakings.

results.title: Man about Europe: Louis Armand
results.creator_credit: Georges Robin, Anthony de Lotbinière and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Pacemakers”.
Louis Armand is the most famous of all France’s civil servant/technocrats - the great moderniser with a clear and steady eye on the needs of people rather than just the capabilities of machines. During the war he organised railway resistance to the Germans, and after the war he was responsible for the electrification of the French National railway system. He persuaded the French to look for oil in the Sahara; he was the man behind Euratom; and is the leader and driving force of the French Channel Tunnel Company.
